conclusion: Car A accelerates uniformly from 0 m/s to 40 m/s in 10 s, then continues at constant speed 40 m/s.
Car B accelerates uniformly from 0 m/s, reaching 40 m/s at t = 20 s and then keeps on accelerating at the same constant rate.
Acceleration of A is 4.0 m/s² for the first 10 s, then 0.
Acceleration of B is 2.0 m/s² all the time.
Their displacements are equal at t = 0 and again at t = 30 s.
At t ≈ 15 s their velocities are equal (both 30 m/s), but the cars are not side-by-side then.
s_A(t) = ½(40)(10) + 40(t − 10) for t ≥ 10 s and s_A(t) = 2t² for t ≤ 10 s.
For 0 ≤ t ≤ 10 s: Δs = s_A − s_B = t².
Maximum Δs for 0 ≤ t ≤ 10: Δs = t² → maximum at t = 10 s, Δs = 100 m.
Check the ends of the interval: Δs(10 s) = 100 m, Δs(30 s) = 0 m.
Thus the largest value is 200 m at t = 20 s.
The greatest distance separating the two cars between the two instants when they are side-by-side is 200 m.
